title: Italian submarine Pietro Calvi
text:
Pietro Calvi was the <a href="lead%20ship">lead ship</a> of <a href="Calvi-class%20submarine">her class</a> of two <a href="submarine">submarine</a>s built for the (Royal Italian Navy) during the 1930s. Completed in 1936, she played a minor role in the <a href="Spanish%20Civil%20War">Spanish Civil War</a> of 1936–1939 supporting the <a href="Francoist%20Spain">Spanish Nationalists</a>. The submarine made multiple patrols in the <a href="Atlantic%20Ocean">Atlantic Ocean</a> during the <a href="Second%20World%20War">Second World War</a>, sinking seven <a href="Allies%20of%20World%20War%20II">Allied</a> ships. "Pietro Calvi" was rammed and sunk by a British convoy escort in July 1942.
Design and description.
The "Calvi" class was an improved and enlarged version of the preceding <a href="submarine%20cruiser">submarine cruiser</a>s. They <a href="Displacement%20%28ship%29">displaced</a> surfaced and submerged. The submarines were long, had a <a href="beam%20%28nautical%29">beam</a> of and a <a href="draft%20%28hull%29">draft</a> of . They had an <a href="Submarine%20depth%20ratings">operational diving depth</a> of . Their crew numbered 77 officers and enlisted men.
For surface running, the boats were powered by two <a href="diesel%20engine">diesel engine</a>s, each driving one <a href="propeller%20shaft">propeller shaft</a>. When submerged each propeller was driven by a <a href="electric%20motor">electric motor</a>. They could reach on the surface and underwater. On the surface, the "Calvi" class had a range of at ; submerged, they had a range of at .
The boats were armed with eight <a href="torpedo%20tube">torpedo tube</a>s, four each in the bow and in the stern for which they carried a total of 16 <a href="torpedo">torpedo</a>es. They were also armed with a pair of <a href="120%20mm%20Italian%20naval%20gun%2345-calibre%20OTO%201931"></a> <a href="deck%20guns">deck guns</a>, one each fore and aft of the <a href="conning%20tower">conning tower</a>, for combat on the surface. Their <a href="Anti-aircraft%20warfare">anti-aircraft armament</a> consisted of two twin-gun mounts for <a href="Breda%20Model%201931%20Machine%20Gun"></a> <a href="machine%20gun">machine gun</a>s.
Construction and career.
"Pietro Calvi" (<a href="pennant%20number">pennant number</a> CV) was built by <a href="OTO%20Melara">Odero-Terni-Orlando</a> at their <a href="Muggiano">Muggiano</a>, <a href="Province%20of%20La%20Spezia">La Spezia</a>, <a href="shipyard">shipyard</a>. <a href="Laid%20down">Laid down</a> in 1932, the submarine was <a href="Ceremonial%20ship%20launching">launched</a> on 31 March 1935 and completed in 1936.
During the Spanish Civil War, she unsuccessfully fired a pair of torpedoes each at the <a href="mail%20steamer">mail steamer</a> and the 3946 GRT mail steamer during a patrol on 1–17 January 1937. During the night of 12/13 January she bombarded the port of <a href="Valencia">Valencia</a>.
The first patrol during the Second World War was from <a href="Liguria">Liguria</a> to the <a href="Atlantic%20Ocean">Atlantic Ocean</a>, and lasted from 3 July to 6 August 1940. After overhaul at La Spezia, "Pietro Calvi" sailed on 6 October for a second Atlantic patrol reaching <a href="Bordeaux">Bordeaux</a>, France, on 23 October. The submarine suffered storm damage during its third patrol off the <a href="British%20Isles">British Isles</a> from 3 to 31 December. The fourth patrol was between the <a href="Canary%20Islands">Canary Islands</a> and the <a href="Azores">Azores</a> from 31 March to 13 May 1941. She sailed on 1 August for a fifth patrol off the Canary Islands. During the sixth patrol from 7 to 29 December "Pietro Calvi", and rescued sailors of the sunken German <a href="commerce%20raider">commerce raider</a> . The seventh patrol was off <a href="Brazil">Brazil</a> from 7 March to 29 April 1942. The submarine sailed on 2 July for its eighth patrol. "Pietro Calvi" was rammed and sunk on 14 July by the British <a href="sloop-of-war">sloop</a> which was able to briefly <a href="Naval%20boarding">board</a> the submarine before she sank. British ships rescued 35 of her crew of 78 men; among those killed was the commanding officer, Commander <a href="Primo%20Longobardo">Primo Longobardo</a>.
